content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
 Half-Life What is there to say about this game? Well actually, alot. This game is absolutely fantastic. Personally, I prefer it over 2. Anyways, with my opinion out of the way, I'm going to elaborate about why this game is so  great.  The story starts with you, Gordon Freeman. The 27 year old scientist with a degree in Theoretical Physics. Not much to say about that. Your workplace, Black Mesa, gets attacked by various aliens and the marines when an transfer goes wrong. The thing about this game is that theres a huge element of surprise. You'll find out what I mean when you play the game. Yea.Plot twists, man.Anyways, the gameplay. That makes the whole game. The gameplay is absolutely fantastic for an FPS. However, this isn't just any FPS with some macho guy ripping monster heads off because it's fun (I'm looking at you, Duke Nukem.)This is, what I would call an action-adventure FPS. This game really set the standard for the genre. There's a fair assortment of weapons. Speaking of weapons, you're going to need ammo. Alot of it.That's not necessarily a bad thing - it's everywhere. Or atleast, it's not very hard to find ammo. The other thing with this game is that, you, the player needs to be very patient. This game has backtracking. Alot of it. Next thing, the graphics. The graphics aged fairly well, in my opinion. Sure, some of the models might look wonky, but it can be easily fixed with a few HD mods. There is music in this game. Although, they only really play during intense parts, it's still quite well composed.If you look past the backtracking and constant dying, you'll love this game. Trust me.It's absolutely fantastic, and really set the standards for the FPS genre after 1998. That's not all I have to say about Half-Life, but if I did, you and I would be here all day. Final Verdict:9.5/10 An absolute fantabulous masterpiece

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												You are Gordon Freeman. A scientist who works for the Black Mesa facility. And an experiment you took part in has gone completely awry, unleashing an extraterestrial invasion, and now all hell has broken loose in Black Mesa. Your main goal is to survive and to stop the invasion, using the help of surviving Black Mesa employees, whatever you can get your hands on and your own bare wits.Even if it is over a decade old, Half Life has aged very, very well. In fact it seems to do some things better than most Modern shooters - you can hold a heck of a lot of weapons for example, a great feature that barely has any presence in shooters nowadays. The gunplay is intense but fair, and you have a huge multitude of weapons to utilise - and they are all great and feel powerful. Enemy types are plentiful, varied and can get pretty darn tough as the game progresses. The enemy AI itself is intelligent and fierce - especially the soldiers who know how to flank well and work together. There are friendly NPC's as well, which are actually helpful: Security guards can help deliver covering fire and scientists can unlock doors and heal you if you are low on health. The game also takes good advantage of the environmental elements around it, technically making almost everything a threat or obstacle - some bridges can be destroyed which may require you to find another way around it, wet floors are obviously slippy so you need to be careful not to slide into an elevator shaft - Did I also mention that elevators in this game are barely ever safe? All of these great uses of particular stage elements called for some fantastically designed levels and puzzles that require a skilled gamer to complete.Graphically, I will admit the game does look a bit blocky by today's standards and the character animations are pretty wooden, but each level within Half Life looks worlds apart from one another, especially the last part of the game, trust me, it's amazing, that's all I'm saying about it, I'm not gonna spoil it. The character and enemy designs themselves, most notably the aliens, are really creative, unique and varied. The real time cutscenes were cutting edge back in the day and even though the choppy and kinda unexistant character animations during these cutscenes are now dated in a sense, the fact that they are REAL TIME just makes them very immersive and makes you feel part of a great story.When it comes to audio, the soundeffects are great and fits Half Life's sci-fi tone, and the guns are LOUD. The music tracks, although few and far between, are fantastic and give off great atmosphere. The voiceacting is also great, even if the recordings are a bit grainy.If there was anything I thought that did detract from the overall quality from the game, is the fact that sometimes the player can get glitched in certain parts of the environment, so they can't move, therefore they would need to restart from the last save... but then again this barely ever happens.Tl;dr Half Life is a groundbreaking FPS that has stood the test of time and I still consider it as one of the best shooters ever made, if not the best. An immersive, action packed, incredibly varied FPS that makes you feel like an action hero. Highly recommended to anyone who has at least an interest in videogames.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Despite its age, Half-Life is still one of the greatest examples of organic storytelling in video games. Valve’s debut title succeeds where most modern games fail—in telling a story without interrupting the game’s pacing or forcing its narrative down the player’s throat.In fact, the only time Half-Life interrupts it’s frenetic pace is to spoon feed you simplistic puzzles designed to showcase Valve’s fancy 'GoldSrc' engine, and while I’m sure it all looked fantastic back in 1998, it’s lost its relevance, and the frequent interruptions to the game are totally arbitrary now that we’ve seen things like physics engines become commonplace.Despite technological shortcomings, the way Half-Life tells a story is better than any that came before it and most that came after it. It’s subtle and understated, favouring brief snippets of dialogue between a pair of marines or a brief set piece of a scientist being dragged into an air duct over lengthy cutscenes of exploding helicopters. It gives an air of realism contrary to the game’s sci-fi setting and sometimes over-the-top tone, and it’s a real testament to the value of organic exposition that such evocative atmospheres can be created through such subtle methods.Surprisingly, Half-Life doesn’t let itself be carried by its storytelling. The narrative is built around solid core gameplay that boasts the tactical complexity of a more modern title on top of the large array of weapons reminiscent of older shooters. As I’ve previously mentioned, the enemy AI is subpar by today’s standards, but it’s really the level design that makes the combat stand out. The environments are varied and engaging in such a way that retains atmospheric consistency while providing some excellent combat scenarios.Half-Life will always be a classic, and despite some janky behaviour that’s become more evident as its aged, it’s a fantastic shooter—easily one of the best to date.

												The first time I came in contact with Half-Life was around 1999, I used to watch my brother play this game, to say the least I was amazed by the graphics and HL world back then. Becoming a CSS regular, I became familiar with CS mods (DR, MG, ZM, BHOP...), having a few thousand hours in CSS.Today, replaying the first Half-Life I came to realize how much of an impact this game had on the whole series, inspiring most of the mods known to todays Counter-Strike community.Beside a very interesting story line, it has a diverse world, completely voiced dialog, awesome weapons and monsters and a legendary status in my book.no less than a 10/10

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												A masterpiece. One of the best first person shooters ever made IMO.The game's highest point is easily its immersion, almost unrivaled even until today, gripping you with its atmosphere and actually putting you in the shoes of a (sort of) Average Joe, who's unlucky enough to be at the wrong place at the wrong time. No cutscenes, no quick time events, no regenerating health, no objective markers cluttering up the screen or excessive handholding, no annoying constant remarks by the protagonist (tbh some games can do a talking protag right, but in this game I feel that a silent protag was perfect for it and used really well), and you're almost never taken away control of Freeman. This all combines with a great setting oozing with atmosphere, memorable enemies such as the headcrab, scripted events that are done in a very natural way to give life to the game world and that trigger often as you explore a space in an organic fashion, lots of environmental storytelling that rewards the player for sticking around to search and listen but doesn't force them to stop, and excellent level design with enough searching and nooks and crannies to explore to not give the feeling of being on rails that other linear games give. It really lets you live and experience the game, not just watch it like a semi-interactive movie as so many modern first person shooters now do.From a more gameplay-wise perspective, the weapons are rather fun to use and enemy AI is surprisingly still decent to this day and age, especially the amazing marine AI. You amass a very large arsenal of around 14 weapons, none feeling superfluous or excessively powerful and all surprisingly balanced and functional, each with their own situational ups and downs. No regenerating health naturally encourages you to be on the move and explore, in search of health packs and health stations (this is definately something you want in an FPS, as instead of the stale taking cover all the time to regen health of other games, you're encouraged to play far more dynamically and actually go out there, move and dodge, scavenge and explore). Movement isn't perfect, it can at times be too sensitive, but the speed but definately far faster and more fluid than the average CoD running speed that feels like you have bowling balls for feet.Cons? Well, if I had to point out problems with the game, then probably the Xen levels, aka the final few levels of the game. The physics in those levels are horrible and really frustrating, the level designs are bad and not fun to play through, and it's mostly a rather disappointing and frustrating last stretch of levels in an otherwise masterpiece game.Overall, 9.5/10, without Xen it would be 10/10, and either way it's a must play for any FPS fan.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is the game that started it all.The thing is,it still holds up;I spent hours and hours playing and replaying this game for the different kinds of actual challenges it offers.You can go up against crazy bosses AND skirmishes with lots of little guys,navigate the terrain and some of the fights with really good twitch reflexes and learning how the level works,old-school arcade style,plus,while it isn't a puzzler,you really do have to think about your environment and figure out how to use it to survive.When they talk about"a workout for your whole brain derp derp"in anything,this is kind of using your whole gaming brain,and it's satisfying.You kind of forget how polygonal and 1990s the graphics are with how richly the world is imagined,and you really do get a sense of Gordon Freeman as a lone,lucky survivor who evolves into a BAMF by natural selection.I do want to say,it's very different from the HL2 games;those are more talky and give us a less isolated Gordon.While you don't get the gravity gun in this game,I found myself wishing for some of the cool weapons available in this game in HL2.I will venture to say that you can't really call yourself an FPS player until you've played HL1.;-)

It deserves your attention. 9/10  Nominated for the “Test of Time” Award

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												Half-Life is a science fiction first-person shooter video game developed by Valve Corporation, the company's first game product and the first in the Half-Life series. Released in 1998 by Sierra Studios , in Half-Life, you assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who must fight his way out of a secret underground research facility whose research and experiments into teleportation technology have gone disastrously wrong. Half-Life is a first-person shooter that requires the player to perform combat tasks and puzzle solving to advance through the game. Compared to most first-person shooters of the time, which relied on cut-scene intermissions to detail their plotlines, Half-Life‍ '​s story is told entirely by means of scripted sequences, keeping you in control of the first-person viewpoint. In line with this, the game has no cut-scenes, and you rarely loses the ability to control Gordon, who never speaks and is never actually seen in the game; the player sees "through his eyes" for the entire length of the game. It also has multiplayer and because this is not the original version, it comes with an HD texture pack, which looks gorgeous in game. Although having not played on an actual servers I have played LAN with one of my friends and in my first experience I thought it was spot on, there are so much maps and also many weapons for you to use. Overall I would give Half-Life a rating of 9/10 stars, for a 1998 game this is absolutely fantastic . The story is very interesting and fun to play through, you feel like you really are playing as Gordon this is an absolutely must buy for a price of $6 you are getting such a great deal. I am absolutely 100% sure without a doubt that Half-Life will just blow you away!.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												ENGDo I recommend this game? Absolutely. It's a great game. And yes, maybe it's graphics have aged a bit, but then so has System Shock's. Whether it's on sale or not, I would recommend it to just about anyone, so here are some pros and cons.Plus-Great music and sound effects. They might be aged like the graphics but they still got it.-Takes the silent protagonist to a whole new level. You'll really feel like you are Gordon Freeman - even if you're a bit mute.-The game has some choices that actually give you different endings for a little variety (not that they carry over to other games).-Despite being a FPS/Survival type game, Half-Life has a godd story that is felt consistently throughout the game.-Balanced gameplay and various difficulties for those of varying confidence.-Unique enemies and weapons.minus-The graphics and sound might not always age well, but this is easily countered by nostalgia.-Though you can go about your journey in varying ways, it is, to an extent, very linear with little real choices. So if branching, choice-driven storylines are your thing, then this is a con. If not, ignore this.So that's it from me. Not much I can say wrong about this game. And in my opinion, the cons were a bit of a stretch. So what are you waiting for? Get the game! Or wait for a sale...THEN get the game!

												around the time this game was released there were two types of video game story types. There was The Doom style, you know that stuff you mistake for credits in between blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up. There was MGS, which felt the need to beat you with exposition until you began to feel like you were a Horse. who was dying. But narrative, true narrative, is not blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up or exposition. It is what half life does. Storytelling through gameplay. It is not a simple shooting gallery, nor is it a movie where you have to do♥♥♥♥♥♥to get past the commercials. It is a game where gameplay and story are inseperable. Half-Life would be dull as a film. And what would it be without the G-Man? I had never played this game before, but I had heard of it. everyone has. It is considered the best of 90's PC gaming(well, it and Deus Ex.) It nails gameplay and storytelling. the tale is compelling, with action, suspense, and a hidden element of mystery.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												It all started with Counter Strike. When I barely knew anything about FPS games on PC. When I was only familiar with Survival Horror games as tank controlled models in 3d environments. Until I played Counter strike with a couple of friends. Some friendships were lost and others were born from that game. A couple of LAN parties later, my curiosity got the better of me and I decided to click on "Play Half Life" Thinking it was a demo for an upcoming multiplayer shooter. I did not know what was in store. I don't think anyone was ready for what Half Life offered, really. I need to emphasize on the fact that throughout my very first 5 to 6 hours, I still thought it was a demo. Headcrabs, crowbars, bleeding scientists running amok, these images still flash before me until today. It feels like yesterday when I tried to pass through the hallway only to get sucked up by a pod infested thing. I think the scariest moment for me was fighting that huge boss from afar, I cant recall his name but the whole experience with Half life was haunting. Only 2 games did I play as a kid where I was literally walking step by step. One was Silent Hill 2, the other was Half Life. By today you should already know what Half Life represents and what it influenced. If you haven't played it, I don't need to tell you what you need to do.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												This game is amazing.  Although hard at times, I enjoyed nearly every bit of this game... all 17 hours of it.  Yup, that's right, it took me 17 hours to complete this game, start to finish, all while heavily relying on a guide.The thing is, older games tend to be a bit harder; ever heard of the term "Nintendo hard?"  Although the modes are linear (not complaining there), often I would think I have gotten lost because of how big the world is, but I then found out I was going in the right direction the entire time, or I would quickly find the right direction.  So that's a nice effect.But for the most part, this game was years ahead of it's time, with dynamic shields, AI, and all sorts of enemies.You would think this is horror, but this is the older generation, based off of arena-based shooters (Quake and Doom), so your movement takes that aspect away (once I was able to jump off a cliff to dodge an electric LoS attack, then airstrafe back onto the cliff to take him out).All in all, this is a fun, fast-paced shooter that I would recommend to anyone.

												around the time this game was released there were two types of video game story types. There was The Doom style, you know that stuff you mistake for credits in between blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up. There was MGS, which felt the need to beat you with exposition until you began to feel like you were a Horse. who was dying. But narrative, true narrative, is not blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up or exposition. It is what half life does. Storytelling through gameplay. It is not a simple shooting gallery, nor is it a movie where you have to do♥♥♥♥♥♥to get past the commercials. It is a game where gameplay and story are inseperable. Half-Life would be dull as a film. And what would it be without the G-Man? I had never played this game before, but I had heard of it. everyone has. It is considered the best of 90's PC gaming(well, it and Deus Ex.) It nails gameplay and storytelling. the tale is compelling, with action, suspense, and a hidden element of mystery.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												It's really hard to say something about Half-Life that hasn't already been said before. The game has been showered with such praise and acclaim since it's inception, even in the modern day. While many people would be ready to just write it off as people looking at it through 'nostalgia goggles', it's really important to go back and look at what makes it such a masterpiece.Half-Life begins in a way that no other shooter at the time had done. Instead of leading off with a mission briefing before throwing you into a room full of demons, or showing you a cutscene to serve as exposition, the game immediately puts you in the shoes of Dr. Gordon Freeman on his fated tram ride as he is late to work. Your control of Freeman is, well, free, and you're free to move about the tram and examine the surroundings of your tram. You, the player, help Freeman get into his HEV Suit, greet his colleagues, and push a specimen of crystal into a large machine which promptly wrecks the facility of Black Mesa. Gordon, with your aid, sets out on an epic quest to escape his workplace, fighting off freakish aliens and later on soldiers who are sent in to perform a cover-up operation. Only in one instance is direct control ever taken away from you and even then you see the event unfold through Freeman's eyes. Story isn't told to you via exposition, but rather by carefully placed scripted events and NPC's you can encounter who inform you of where to go next.Half-Life's story, or rather the way it tells it's story still manages to be as immersive as it was when I first played it, way back in 2009. Gordon isn't some lunkheaded badass space marine who rips and tears the guts of his enemies but rather a normal person who just happens to be donning a powerful suit of experimental armor that prevents him from the same type of swift deaths that his co-workers are so subjected to. Black Mesa isn't a laid out level filled with awkward enemy traps that forces you to run around looking for arbitrary keycards to progress but rather a research facility that feels real and legitimate to go through, and it's still one of the most believable enviroments in a shooter today. The way the enemies interact with their environment makes them feel like actual living beings.Of course, all of this wouldn't be anywhere near as good if the gameplay wasn't there as well. Thankfully, the combat in Half-Life is as visceral as other FPS games of it's time, featuring a wide array of weapons with meaty sound effects. Gordon's first weapon is his Iconic crowbar, which you wont be using so much as a weapon later on and more of as a 'hand' so to speak, it'll be the weapon you use to smash apart the environment to see what is and what isn't breakable, or to smash open a crate to gain supplies. Your ranged arsenal is very diverse, featuring basic weapons like a Submachine Gun, a Shotgun, and a Revolver to the Tau cannon, something akin to a wind up rail gun from quake, to a tranqulizer dart crossbow that you'll primarily be using to fight off underwater and aerial threats.The weapons themselves are great but what makes them so fun to use is the fact that the enemies are just as diverse and require different strategies to take down. Something like a headcrab should be killed with the crowbar or the glock so as to not waste ammo, but faster, stronger moving targets like the HECU marines will be more easily dispatched with weapons like the MP5 or the Spas-12. You'll even come accross a giant hulking alien which is imperveous to all types of damage except for explosions. The sound designs on all the enemies is spot on, with the HECU sounding suitably intimidating over the radio comms, or the eerie roars of the Gargantua. This already solid gameplay is also helped by various other factors, like level design. I already mentioned that Black Mesa feels like a real place, and so the Level Design is often in close quarters, with enemies often hiding around corners and enemies like the HECU marines will take advantage of the various routes they can take to flank you, just as you are able to do the same. The game also features in my opinion one of the best VGM soundtracks out there, with songs like "Diabolical Adrenaline Guitar", "Nuclear Mission Jam", and the Credits theme standing out as some of my favorites in particular. When the soundtrack wants you to feel like a badass, it will, and when it wants to be atmospheric, it will. Valve's sound team was absolutely on point here, as the game and it's various sound effects, quotes and music all feel spot on.Half-Life isn't without a few flaws here and there though.  The game slows down towards the middle, with two chapters On a Rail and Residue Processing feeling a little tedious to play through, and with the final levels of Xen outside of the final boss being incredibly annoying and un-fun to play through. It seems like there was some pact between FPS devs of the time to make the final levels of their games to be as stupid as possible, but even then I really don't think these are enough to truly hurt the game. Half-Life is remembered so fondly not just because of itself as a game, but also the way it revolutionized the Genre. So many other FPS games tried to follow in it's wake, and it still remains one of the most influential FPS games of all time.Half-Life is without a doubt one of my personal favorite games of all time, as well in my opinion being worthy of being called one of the best games of all time. Half-Life is a game that combines an unbroken narrative with kick♥♥♥♥♥gameplay, strong and realistic level design with a rockin' soundtrack to create one of the most celebrated games ever created. I didn't even touch upon the huge collection of high-quality free mods available for the game, but they absolutely exist. They Hunger, Afraid of Monsters and Poke646 stand out as some of my favorite mods for any game. Half-Life is absolutely worth your time and money, and you owe it to yourself to play it if you consider yourself a video game enthusiast.

Posted: October 31, 2016
												If you have not played this game, then you have never experienced life. This is the finest work of art in storytelling and visuals you will get in your entire life. Half Life comes from a time where effort in games was a thing, and Valve created this symphony in such a perfect form, to allow the game of the century to be born. The game has aged fantastically, the visuals are intense and intriguing, and keep a surprisingly realistic feel for the limited hardware at the time, 1997-1998. It's amazingly natural to be immersed into this game.Pros - Everything in this game is pleasure at its most pure.Cons - Why the bloody hell don't you own Half Life?!Rating - 1,000,000/10(I have a low amount of hours since my Steam account is relatively new as of 2016. I primarily played the disc version of Half Life as well as the Playstation 2 version, while owning the Steam version since 2013 on a different account.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												This game is a classic. It doesn't matter if I recommend it or not, you should probably at least try it.As most of you know, you are Gordon Freeman, scientist or something from Black Mesa and you basically save the ♥♥♥♥ing world. This first-person shooter combines a wide variety of weapons - Assault rifles, SMGs, pistols, grenades and crowbars with an amazing story and perfectly crafted levels. I understand why this game is regarded as a classic, the levels are truly made beautifully.Aside from being a great single player game, it also spawned a lot of community made mods, which were later created into standalone games. Popular ones like Counter-Strike, Day of Defeat, Team Fortress Classic and even Ricochet all started from Half-Life.To be honest, though, with the amount of praise it gets, I somehow expected a lot more, even though I knew it's an old game and I was a bit disappointed. Movement also felt a bit slippery.Overall, It's definitely not a bad idea to buy it.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												All the new age shooters (otherwise known as would-be games) seem to be coming out with a little less flare each time these days so there is only one thing left for me to do; masturb… I mean play old shooters. In Half Life you play silent protagonist number B. He differs from others because he has the power of the beard and a MIT degree that obviously had no concept of oral presentations. When it was released Half Life posed a new stage of interactive storytelling. But really it just means you’re allowed to turn away from all major plot points and stare at the wall. Still, the notion of alien invasions and government cover-ups are very popular themes as my good friend, Fox Mulder, will tell you. Instead I saw Half Life as the story of the nerds overpowering the jocks and saving the world that we desperately needed.Half Life went down in history as an amazing game and the introduction of raging, hormone filled teenagers to the gaming scene via the mod Counter Strike. A spine chiller looked at in comparison to Hitler nowadays. I found myself playing through Half Life many times in the small fraction of my life I have experienced (This joke would have been better if I could say half my life) and I still have one question. Why is Gordon Freeman a hero when, during my play throughs, the scientists he is supposed to be saving served him better as meat shields? A question as mysterious to me as the G-man. Last time I was called the G-man followed the statement “you hit the spot,” during several of my ‘biology’ practices. And no, those didn’t occur at MIT.

												Don't let the old graphics or old date fool you...this is hands down one of the best games ever made, sparking not only the hugely succesfful Half-Life series but also the Portal series. No, this game invovles a lot of the thinking involved in Portal (although on a much smaller scale)--there's no objective dot like in Call of Duty. Definitely a must buy. And the multiplayer, however cheesy it may seem, is simply incredible. I never knew how accurate hip-firing could be...(Buy it and you'll see what I mean).

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												This game has been legendary since it's release in 1998, it has won over 50 game of the year of awards. If you have a pc of any kind, get this game. Because the story is good, it runs on a potato, there is fast-paced fun multiplayer, supports mods that make the game way better, and the whole game is fun.And if you don't have another reason for half-life then heres this: Half-Life SDK. The ultimate tool to putting your ideas from pen to paper, to a three-dimensional world that supports 32-bit coloured textures, ambient sounds that is really immersive, a top-notch visibility engine so everymap you play in is optimized for your pc, and aswell as high-poly models that can be created. Half-Life SDK WILL be in your LIBRARY-TOOLS folder upon buying Half-Life, for only 10 dollars.And in courtesy of Mapcore.org and Game Bannana, you can download maps to enhance your experience, or why not install a mod where you play as another black mesa employee, trying to escape the HECU marines aswell as the Xen creatures.I will never regret purchasing this game, it has filled me with experiences that I can always relive with a click of the blue PLAY button that sits in your library as you are bored and want to play a fun game. Buy this game, I don't care if your broke, get a small loan from the mafia or get a big one from the bank, just buy it.10/10 -ShoXiN

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												This game is amazing.  Although hard at times, I enjoyed nearly every bit of this game... all 17 hours of it.  Yup, that's right, it took me 17 hours to complete this game, start to finish, all while heavily relying on a guide.The thing is, older games tend to be a bit harder; ever heard of the term "Nintendo hard?"  Although the modes are linear (not complaining there), often I would think I have gotten lost because of how big the world is, but I then found out I was going in the right direction the entire time, or I would quickly find the right direction.  So that's a nice effect.But for the most part, this game was years ahead of it's time, with dynamic shields, AI, and all sorts of enemies.You would think this is horror, but this is the older generation, based off of arena-based shooters (Quake and Doom), so your movement takes that aspect away (once I was able to jump off a cliff to dodge an electric LoS attack, then airstrafe back onto the cliff to take him out).All in all, this is a fun, fast-paced shooter that I would recommend to anyone.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												This game is a classic. It doesn't matter if I recommend it or not, you should probably at least try it.As most of you know, you are Gordon Freeman, scientist or something from Black Mesa and you basically save the ♥♥♥♥ing world. This first-person shooter combines a wide variety of weapons - Assault rifles, SMGs, pistols, grenades and crowbars with an amazing story and perfectly crafted levels. I understand why this game is regarded as a classic, the levels are truly made beautifully.Aside from being a great single player game, it also spawned a lot of community made mods, which were later created into standalone games. Popular ones like Counter-Strike, Day of Defeat, Team Fortress Classic and even Ricochet all started from Half-Life.To be honest, though, with the amount of praise it gets, I somehow expected a lot more, even though I knew it's an old game and I was a bit disappointed. Movement also felt a bit slippery.Overall, It's definitely not a bad idea to buy it.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												Half-Life is quite possibly one of the most important first-person shooters ever created. You're not a space marine: you're a scientist fighting for your life. You truly feel alone when your only companion--be it a scientist or one of the many security guards trapped with you--bites the dust, leaving you to fend for yourself. Seamlessly flowing from cinematics to action, there are no cutscenes: the control is never taken from you. Your journey through Black Mesa begins.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I give this game a 8.5/10 overall. -The "story" is great even there is lack of information. The story is that a experiment goes wrong which opens a portal and aliens destroy the whole facility, the player needs to kill aliens and close the portal to save the day.-The gamplay is for me 7.5/10 because sometimes the directions are unclear and what you need to do is sometimes hard to understand. For example I got to a area which had many enemies and very little health packs, I found myself frustrated dying over and over again. in the same area a npc got stuck in a door and he needed to help me open a door (where health packs and ammo was found in), I had to consult a online guide to understand what I needed to do. Sometimes I got stuck in objects and sometimes the game crashed.-The graphics are "bad" (by todays standards) but dosent affect the gameplay, I really didnt notice the fact that they are "bad" and still enjoyed the game.-Otherwise I think the game is great and I highly recommend it to people a great game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is a masterpiece. I'm pretty sure I'm not the first to say that, but it really feels like one. Many things in this game make it what it is. First, the gameplay in this game is just marvelous, you can't feel closer to the game with its amazing mechanisms, shooting, jumping and everything you can do, it just feels right. It seems like it's really you that controls the game and that the final result, good or bad, is always the product of your moves. With great shooting and movement mechanisms, everything feels right.Secondly, another thing you can't complain about this game: its story. The story of Half-Life, the one that gave birth to this amazing franchise, is just a beautiful piece of work. It fully accomplishes its mission to take you to another world. With the fact that, Gordon Freeman, the character which you control, is entirely in your possession feels like you are in this story and you have the power to change it. The game doesn't even have cutscenes so everything is seen from your point of view. The story is captivating; it treats the alien subject differently from most stories told on this subject. It contains a government trying to hide the alien-incident, a mysterious G-Man (the man who always watches you) and a chaotic man vs alien battlefield. Maybe after all, they're not what we thought... So many questions will fly around your head and will give you the desire to continue this mysterious story.Thirdly, I have to talk about the graphics and the level design. Those both, like everything I said before, are just truly great. While the graphics may be considered "ugly" or "old", they are for me still beautiful even if this game is from 1998. The game has great details, textures and colors. Just imagine how it felt back in the days. For the level design, nothing as changed. What I mean by that, is even after more than a decade, the levels are still pure genius and are so well used that you need to think and to familiarize with them so you can use them as your advantage. I have to tell you that this game isn't like most of the games today and is longer, which is really nice, because you'll want this game to never end. There is also a multiplayer mode which can be fun, but, as you guessed it, is mostly dead. From a negative point of view, I don't have a lot to say. For the people that won't like the graphics, you can always buy the Black Mesa game, which is the same thing, but updated for the new generations (or old time fans). All I can say in the end, is that this game is a must!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												"Half-life (abbreviated t1⁄2) is the time required for a quantity to reduce to half its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo, or how long stable atoms survive, radioactive decay." Developed by Valve in 1998, released by Sierra Studios for Microsoft Windows, Half-Life was Valve's debut product in what would become an iconic series. You assume the silent role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a young physicist who's late for work. After a teleportation experiment goes horribly wrong, lots of alien based death ensues.It's hard to ignore what Half-Life did for gaming as a whole. Much of PC gaming had become ominously quiet around that time whilst consoles enjoyed a surge in popularity. Then like a head crab from a dimensional fracture, this appeared.Though it can be considered a little janky by modern standards, there's still a lot of fun to be had fighting your way through the black mesa complex. Plus the game can run on a veritable potato.If you've never played this before, why?

The game that started a cult..Half-life is first-person, adventure game developed by Valve Software. You play as Gordon Freeman, a research assistant who just arrived at Black Mesa (a research company) on his first day at work. As you can imagine things go wrong quickly and Mr Freeman is forced to save earth from a terrible foe...The Good+ Excellent story+ Wide variety of foes+ Great assortment of weapons+ Intense firefights+ Smart platforming+ Graphics hold up well+ Active multiplayer+ ModsThe Bad- Navigation = It's easy to get lost when playing in these huge maps whith a lack of directional markers and map.- Limited setting = The course of the game features differeent areas around the Black Mesa compound.- No subtitles- Voice audio too lowSummaryOveral this is a great action-adventure game that should be played by half-life fans and any one who is interested in the genre.

Posted: February 13, 2016
												I give this game a 8.5/10 overall. -The "story" is great even there is lack of information. The story is that a experiment goes wrong which opens a portal and aliens destroy the whole facility, the player needs to kill aliens and close the portal to save the day.-The gamplay is for me 7.5/10 because sometimes the directions are unclear and what you need to do is sometimes hard to understand. For example I got to a area which had many enemies and very little health packs, I found myself frustrated dying over and over again. in the same area a npc got stuck in a door and he needed to help me open a door (where health packs and ammo was found in), I had to consult a online guide to understand what I needed to do. Sometimes I got stuck in objects and sometimes the game crashed.-The graphics are "bad" (by todays standards) but dosent affect the gameplay, I really didnt notice the fact that they are "bad" and still enjoyed the game.-Otherwise I think the game is great and I highly recommend it to people a great game.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2010
												While DOOM really established the FPS, it was Half-Life that really took it to the next level. Valve created something so amazing, so different to anything else on the market at the time. Not a straight up shooter, but one where you were actually IN a story. Events were happening around you, and you were participating in them. Enemies were not just wheeled out wave after wave, they were smarter. Things happened when you seemed to be walking down an empty corridor, nothing was straightforward in this game. Many features in Half-Life will now seem standard, but next to DOOM, this is the game that changed the FPS in to what it is today. But while playing DOOM might only provide you with some retro nostalgia for a few minutes, Half-Life is still a very playable classic.

												Half-Life is quite possibly one of the most important first-person shooters ever created. You're not a space marine: you're a scientist fighting for your life. You truly feel alone when your only companion--be it a scientist or one of the many security guards trapped with you--bites the dust, leaving you to fend for yourself. 												The first thing anybody is going to notice in this game is the graphics. They're very dated, and sit somewhere in between Playstation and Playstation 2, but don't let this turn you off from this classic. I originally bought this just to fill the gap in story before Half Life 2, but found it to be an extremely fun and intermittently terrifying old-school survival horror FPS. This comes complete with the ability to Friendly-fire on any civillian you wish and enemies you'll come to hate, placed so strategically as to force you to go away from the health pack you desperately need because you don't have enough health to face them in the first place.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												An excellent game in its own right. Valves first masterpiece which inspired the sequels (HL2, Ep 1 & 2) and countless mods throughout the series, such as the acclaimed Team Fortress 2 and Portal.The player starts of as a researcher in Black Mesa running late to work. After the Gordon Freeman, the character the player controls, reaches the test he is supposed to participate in he is immediately put to work. This has cataclysmic consequences, and Gordon Freeman is then forced to defend Black Mesa from an alien invasion and, eventually, the military, all the while being followed by the mysterious G-man.In terms of gameplay, Half-Life is very simple. You have health and suit power, a variety of guns and hopeully some aim. Starting with a crowbar and ending with a laser, you will shoot your way through Black Mesa, solving simple puzzles and navigating sometimes complex coridoors.The plot is simple yet effective, as is the gameplay. Overall, a very satisfying game, and worth checking out regardless of reviews, due to its impact.

												half-life 1 possibly the greatest FPS ever made (sue me COD fanboys) when i was a teenager i wasted literally years of time in this game on my old 350Mhz pentium 2 tower with 64MB of RAM in 640x480 res with a 2MB graphics cardthis is a classic and no real review is required but for completion sake i will write one anyway pros:this game will run on literally any computer made after 2000 even without a dedicated GPUmultiplayer is fun when you can find someone to play withthe graphics still hold up today in my opinion if you use direct 3D or open GL mode at max resthe level design was exquisite for its time and is still good today you get a wide range of weapons to use from the legendary crowbar to an alien beehive (did i mention i hate bees!!!)the gore from falls and explosions (or even the crowbar) is still unmatched in detail by most modern games the voice acting is really good for the time by adjusting the text in the speech files sometimes you can make characters swear at youyou can even shoot a tanks main cannon and watch alien guts fly everywhere the rerplay value is high on this one and i would play it any day cons:it sometimes doesnt work properly on newer computers and operating systems most of the time you will have ammo for the guns that are all but useless late in the game (ever played shotgun vs helicopter?)the end boss is near impossible to beat the first time until you look up a walkthroughthe protection missions (protect this scientist from aliens) are hard as♥♥♥♥♥♥because tanking is not a useful tacticheadcrabs come out of nowhere before you can shoot them so you WILL take damage bottom line: get this game get this game get this game why are you still reading this get this game get this game seriously what are you waiting for vote this review as helpful and buy the game its only a dollar or 2

content:
Posted: April 7
												The best FPS ever.  Its sequel, which is an excellent game, comes fairly close, but is it as good considering its era?  No.One can only hope the team that is remaking/has remade this classic thoroughly finishes up Black Mesa... maybe spice things up a bit in the chapter "Surface Tension", as well as everything else that has been acknowledged by people ect.  I applaud the product they already have released and would recommended that entirely, and at the time of this writing they have not finished it quite yet.  Black Mesa even in its current state enthralled this fan.  (edited for Jesus and the FCC).I guess by now you want me to talk about this game and not its remake.  Well, this is a very old game and the visuals are horrendous by todays standards.  A few aspects of the visuals perhaps are not too bad though considering its contemporaries, but it isn't nice looking and you will need to mod the game if possible to make it look nicer.  Still, you can play it in a more acceptable, modern high resolution on screens that some people wish they had back then.  You run around bashing boxes up with a crowbar in a bright orange high-tech suit that deflects 30mm bullets from an Apache, killing aliens, marines, and ninja CIA agents.. and sometimes a scientist or security guard on accident.The story is quite amazing though, and if you have played the sequel it might be very enjoyable for you even if you can't stand the graphics, at first.  I guess Ridley Scott wouldn't want to make a film based on it if the story was that lackluster.  But don't expect any biracial damsels to save you this time.Nevermind, my mistake, it is JJ Abrams I guess. Too bad.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												"Half-life (abbreviated t1⁄2) is the time required for a quantity to reduce to half its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo, or how long stable atoms survive, radioactive decay." Developed by Valve in 1998, released by Sierra Studios for Microsoft Windows, Half-Life was Valve's debut product in what would become an iconic series. You assume the silent role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a young physicist who's late for work. After a teleportation experiment goes horribly wrong, lots of alien based death ensues.It's hard to ignore what Half-Life did for gaming as a whole. Much of PC gaming had become ominously quiet around that time whilst consoles enjoyed a surge in popularity. Then like a head crab from a dimensional fracture, this appeared.Though it can be considered a little janky by modern standards, there's still a lot of fun to be had fighting your way through the black mesa complex. Plus the game can run on a veritable potato.If you've never played this before, why?

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Quake 2's younger brother that went on to throw valve into the lime lightWhile fast paced and simple, Half-Life comes off as a bore to me now that I've given it a good clean run through again. While it's story never breaks line from Gordon's perspective, they don't elaborate on any of the characters or enviroments at all, making interaction with scientists and guards either "keep them alive" or "waste them for laughs".Level design, however, is this games strong point. Every map is huge and expansive, with some great texture work for a game released in 1998. The Dam scene remains one of my favorite uses of Quake II engine technology to this day.It's basically Quake 2 in lab settings. The most interesting chapter is probably Xen, with it's bizarre landscapes.Multiplayer isn't horrible.7/10 it's good

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												This is such a fun game even though it came out in 1998. But it does have its fair share of pros and cons.The main thing i loved about this game is the amont of variety in it, at one point you'll be fighting three gaint claws then hinding from a helicopter in a mine field, then fighting a huge fish underwater with a crossbow. You'll be faced with something new every time, which is somthing most games need to stay fun. Another great thing was the amount of different wepons you keep finding thoughout the entire game, so by the end you have somthing like 20 different wepons (with most of then having a right click secondary fire).The graphics in the game were terrible (but it was made in 1998 so thats ok). The level design was ok (but sometimes you crouch lower then you thought was posible). There is no sprint, only nomal, walk and crouch. The AI sucked, because they somtimes have too fast or too slow reactions, it's really hard to sneak up on them, they occasionly shoot at you before they've finished turning to face you, and some enemys kill you instantly (but your speed make up for most of these problems with the AI). I couldn't understand the plot most of the time (because there is no cut scenes) and the ending was a bit disappointing, it was slightly to sudden.Most of these problems were because it came out in 1998.Which doesn't matter because i loved the game7.5/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												This is such a fun game even though it came out in 1998. But it does have its fair share of pros and cons.The main thing i loved about this game is the amont of variety in it, at one point you'll be fighting three gaint claws then hinding from a helicopter in a mine field, then fighting a huge fish underwater with a crossbow. You'll be faced with something new every time, which is somthing most games need to stay fun. Another great thing was the amount of different wepons you keep finding thoughout the entire game, so by the end you have somthing like 20 different wepons (with most of then having a right click secondary fire).The graphics in the game were terrible (but it was made in 1998 so thats ok). The level design was ok (but sometimes you crouch lower then you thought was posible). There is no sprint, only nomal, walk and crouch. The AI sucked, because they somtimes have too fast or too slow reactions, it's really hard to sneak up on them, they occasionly shoot at you before they've finished turning to face you, and some enemys kill you instantly (but your speed make up for most of these problems with the AI). I couldn't understand the plot most of the time (because there is no cut scenes) and the ending was a bit disappointing, it was slightly to sudden.Most of these problems were because it came out in 1998.Which doesn't matter because i loved the game7.5/10

												i give this game : 9.6i was watching a video ( a game review ) by some one who was saying how good was counter strike and how bad was global offenssive, saying therse no improvement whatsoever, and after playing both game i agree with him.But we all know that half life is like the single player story mode of counter strike.They share the same engine, the same graphics, the same content, and the same ai and gameplay and son on and on...so i finished half life ! now the guy in the video was stating that no one knew why counter strike was good so no one could make it better which seemed right at the time.but after finishing half life i understood why counter strike (10/10) was so Good !!!If developers make a game and dont be concered about graphics and be concered about the LAW and MATH of EVERY SINGLE CONTENT that ever come to a game from code to its last detail and put all the assets on a similar scale a new counter strike will be REBORN !UPDATE : THIS HAS ALMOST HAPPENED AND ITS CALLED RAINBOW SIX SIEGE NOW !now to the game itself :i promise you even if u play this game RIGHT NOW u  will ENJOY THE HELL OUT OF IT.The game is old schooled , just the way i like it, its hard, you cant just press buttons to pass, you actually have to be a hero !And NO NO NO your character in game shouldnt be BATMAN or superman or glueman or any other crappy man for that matter, YOU THE PLAYER SHOULD BE THE HERO !The game test your skills, requires you to be smart and fast, give a nice story for its game and gameplay and year it was made.The graphics are old but due to lack of particles, which is a good thing, you wont tyre your eyes all the time to simulate an effect with no good use, you can play the game in long hours easily, and believe me it will require LONG hours to finish !if u play a little the game attracts you and you wouldnt mind the graphics anyway.But at first it will be a little odd, but i think there is a remastered in hd version on steam called black mesa, so you can play that too, but i had to experience the original thing first .This is the hardcore PC game you are looking for !i give this game : 9.6reviewed by IMMORTALEADER

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												EA really♥♥♥♥♥♥the bed with this one. Ever since the release of the greatest and first shooter video game ever, South Park: The Game, EA has been trying to dismantle the lead that Square Enix deservingly took with their masterpiece. It was apparent that EA took heavily from Square Enix's SP:TG (as us educated game critics call it) with the release of their lowest rated video game ever released, Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, which is essentially SP:TG with a tower defense/RTS element haphazardly implemented. Half-Life may be the worst video game I've ever played, but it still holds a place in my heart. This game represents the downfall of EA, who had brought in the past relatively ok RPGs such as Glover, Alladin, and Space Channel 5: Part 2. Half-Life is the bottom line. Everyone should play this game, if only to steer clear of accidentally doing something that this game did if they plan on developing a game. There is no redeemable quality to be had here. 9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | 2 *3*] = ~88% (75%-100%)It was great back then when it came out, one of those ground-breaker games that showed us what could be done in a video game. A shooter where you're not actually constantly shooting but also experience some civilized situations, like e.g. at the beginning of Doom 3, allowing a much deeper sense of immersion and role-playing.HL is also one of the first 3D 1st person games to have scripted events. It was pretty revolutionary back then to see e.g. how a laser wandering around the room destroys equipment just when you're in the right place to witness it.Much love went into making this game. Sometimes I believe that the actual intention/attitude somehow reflects in a work, not just the craftsmanship. See also System Shock 2 - at least that's how I explain a good portion of its magic.If you want to play it today for the game instead of as an attempt to find out what the people back then might have experienced, play Black Mesa instead. It's a worthy remake of Half-Life.

												Half-Life is a FPS, but not a average FPS, this game brings in shooting and platforming at the right times, sometimes managing the jumping puzzles can be hard, even when the answer is in plain sight and hard to see, completing it feels satisfying. The game can be difficult espically at times when coming to some parts (unless your on easy) making that feel good when you complete it too. The soundtrack is a good part of this game too, and by good, I mean amazingly good. Some of my favorite songs in the game are the following: Hazardous Enviroments, Nuclear Mission Jam, Klaxon Beat, Diabolical Adrenaline Guitar, and Jungle Drums. Overall, being one of the best (and first!) content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												This game still holds as one of the best first person shooters, specially because of it's multiplayer. It hasn't aged that well, unlike it's successor. Glitches in the single player campaign can be very annoying, but if you like old games, you must play this. It's a very long game, has little focus on story, so the action is nonstop as you travel trough a lot of different environments, the gameplay never gets boring. And if you already played Black Mesa Source, I still recommend this just because of the multiplayer.The multiplayer is very unique and fun. The different kinds of alien weaponry and the possibility to use some of then to move and jump around makes it very hard to master. I always return to play it because the multiplayer on modern war games always bores me, trying to be realistic and balanced, while in Half-Life you just make a mess with ridiculously overpowered weapons and movement mechanics, it's fast, it's awesome. Half-Life 2 Deathmatch was just not the same in comparison. If Valve decides to make Half-Life 3's multiplayer just like the first game, with more maps, more overpowered alien weapons, faster movement, and a remake of the crossfire map, it will be the best multiplayer game ever, outselling all Call of Duty games combined.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I honestly don't know why you're reading a review for Half-Life instead of buying it and all the other HL games, but anyway, since there are so many reviews already explaining why it's good, I'm just not gonna do that. Instead I'll just write the story of why I bought it, or mainly how I got into Steam Way back in 2012 when I was first introduced to the internet and memes, I had seen many Half Life 3 memes and I was curious as to why it was so popular, but I never bothered to research it and just went along with it. Eventually, in 2013, I created a Steam account (or maybe it was in late 2012) because of people talking about TF2 and I wanted to see what made it so great, so I downloaded TF2 and I didn't really understand how to play or what I was doing then I lost my login credentials to my Steam account and created 2 more before I finally got to this one. I didn't use Steam much at the time other than to play TF2 and I got my friends involved, too. After a while I went outside my TF2 bubble and started browsing games during a Christmas sale and bought 2 games that got a lot of attention on the internet as well, Fallout 3 and Skyrim. I played them almost 24/7 and then summer came and the 2014 summer sale started, but I had to miss out because I spent 2/3 of the summer away from home. When I came home I got back on Steam and then in August school started up, but that didn't stop me from browsing Steam and building a wishlist (I rarely got money at the time) and I found half-Life and all the other Half-Life games so I wishlisted them all. As time passed, my library grew, my wishlist shrunk, but the Half-Life games always stayed. Then, sometime in March I bought a $20 Steam wallet card and used it to buy a $10 game off my wishlist and I saved the rest for when I had more money to get a more expensive game. Then next week Lego games went on sale and I added another $5 to my account so I had $15, enough to get the Lego Batman trilogy (or at least one of the 2 I didn't own) but then I realized I could get the complete HL 1 anthology for $15 so I bought it, and played Half-Life then fell in love with the series

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												There's not really much I can say about a fifteen year-old game that hasn't already been said, but Half-Life still holds up as a fantastic first-person shooter. The game has aged wonderfully, playing as a great mixture of arena classics like Quake and more "tactical" shooters such as Battlefield or Call of Duty, along with (very hit or miss) light platforming elements and occasional puzzle-solving. In the realm of modern shooters, looking back to classics like Half-Life is a great way to get to better understand how gaming has evolved and how changed many elements of gaming have become over the years.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												The legendary FPS that started it all! It is easily described with its memorable tagline, "Run. Think. Shoot. Live." Let us analyze it in depth, now, shall we?"Run" - fast-paced action that slows only for puzzles"Think" - use your brain for clever mind-benders well-integrated into the game's combat as well as strategizing what weapons to use"Shoot" - self-explanatory. Excellent gunplay is excellent gunplay; not to mention each weapon is unique serving its own purpose."Live" - Add an "A" to the start of it, and that is how you will feel when you play this game thanks to the exceptional combination of everything above plus awesome sci-fi elements, story, soundtrack, and community-made modsEverything about this game is exceptional. I cannot emphasize how much you should try this game. Trust me, you won't be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Half-Life is one of those games that really stands out against a majority of titles. It's main goal is to immerse you into it's world and challenge you time after time again. Visuals - 10/10 For the 90's, beautifully atmospheric. Gameplay - 10/10 Fantastic gameplay, so enticing and hypnotic, you'll swear you'll forget who you were for a second. Story - 10/10 It's not that complex of a story, something goes wrong in the facility and you have to escape. However, complexity aside, it does manage to get a premise where you, as Gordon Freeman, do not understand everything that happens to you. Overall, recommended all the ♥♥♥♥ing way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Oke where do I start. First of all I thought this was a linear singleplayer fps game because I didn't know better after the likings of Call of Duty singleplayers. Oh boy was I wrong! You need to play this game more like Duke Nukem 3D. It's a shooter, platformer/puzzle all in one very neat package with a great story on it's own but even better in combination with Half-Life 2 (where's Half-Life 3?!). I feel dumb but I really needed a walkthrough for this game. Most of the things weren't that difficult as I discovered afterwards, but as a person playing the wrong games for a long time (looking at you again CoD!) I really didn't know what to do at certain points. So valve assumes you have something resembling a brain when playing this game. Shooting and guns feel great. Animations are good too. Only thing that feels old are the textures and models but what do you expect from a game this old? Of course being on PC offers great options like texture mods or even complete overhauls/standalones with Black Mesa being the most popular. Only thing is, the last part of the game is not ready for Black Mesa yet so that's why I didn't play that instead.Only thing I didn't sometimes like was the jumping. After a jump you seem to 'slip away' but maybe that's just me. Not really worth mentioning but sometimes It was frustrating to jump from one platform to another. If you want to rush a quick singleplayer game DO NOT play this game, this game is not for you. It's not the quick-fix singleplayer game you want to blast through in a couple mere hours. You need to relax and take time to play this jewel. And when you do, you will be rewarded a great experience that will change your look on singleplayers.PS: Go buy Half-Life 2 if you don't have it already!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I'm new to Steam and was extremely excited to find this masterpiece available. It was the first game I downloaded, in fact. I'm pleased to say that Half Life is just as good now as it was back in the late 90's when i first stepped through the door into the Black Mesa Research Facility. The compelling storyline; the immersiveness of the environment; so well crafted that it's still easy to see how this game defined a genre - and it still holds up today. I'll say no more about it, I know i'm preaching to the choir here, who doesnt love this game?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												It's refreshing to still be able to play and enjoy an old jewel like this game, and for those of you young enough not to know the importance of this game, back in its day this classic shooter revolutionized the industry. And now we can enjoy it once again understanding the game's age and that we can't possibly expect it to be on par with modern titles in terms of looks. I played the game through several playthroughs, and at the difficulty I played it, it was quite challenging with quite a few reloads to get it done. This quick save/reload cycle is pretty much an inherent part of how the game plays and it got VERY annoying with several instances me getting close to rage quit it. However the game always won me back no matter what! I encountered little bugs in my experience with it, and I didn't play it in my normal gaming rig but instead in a very crappy laptop. This was due to an idea I have that games from the pre-1080p era should be played in laptops so that they don't look too pixelated and the game played very smoothly with very little bugs.Conclusion: This game is a very nice retro experience, challenging to the point of making you rage quit, but with the power of winning you back after every cry of anger!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												When this game first came out, it was, for many, the most awesome thing that could ever happen. Half-Life is a classic FPS and has a lot nostalgic value. The game which holds up even today.Good things in Half-Life:- Classic game which (most likely) every gamer has at least tried- Quite a long game, which just doesn't suddenly stop- It can be difficult but ain't nowhere near impossible and frustration- Good library of modsBad things in Half-Life:- Might not be a good choice if you are a bit younger and want a realistic-looking FPS. It's a old game with old graphics.- Enemy AI can be very stupid sometimes- There's not that many different enemiesI would recommend this for older gamers who have experience in old games. Also this game suits for those who seeks treasures from past.I wouldn't recommend this game for those who wants awesome new graphics and realistic physics.Points: 7 / 10 (..as a HL-fan I'll give 9.7/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game is a Milestone for FPS's, and Video Games in general. Although I prefer the Portal Series (and HL2 was far surperior to its predecessor), this game still deserves the praise it gets. I'll be honest, this game's controls haven't aged the best; everything is slippery and way too fast. But, with a game from '98, that is to be expected. Despite minor hiccups in the control department, everything else checks out: the graphics look great for the time and still look good today, the story is interesting (even if it's rarely explained), and it can be very challenging at times. Almost everyone has already played this game so me telling you to get it won't do much, but still I implore everyone who hasn't played this gem to pick it up ASAP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I can get how people would not like this game, with today's gameplay and graphics. Compared to COD and Battlefield, Half-Life seems a bit unrefined (particularly in movement, as you tend to slide... a lot). But, what Half-Life does have going for it is immersion and a story- both of which are very well-handled. You see things go on around you, that make it seem like you're actually a part of something so much bigger, and that you're actions can bring about some greater change. The ending, while vague, leaves me anticipating the second Half-Life, whenever I play it.

I recommend you grab the valve complete pack or the orange box instead of this on it's own though.9/10.

It's a shooter, platformer/puzzle all in one very neat package with a great story on it's own but even better in combination with Half-Life 2 (where's Half-Life 3?!). I feel dumb but I really needed a walkthrough for this game. Most of the things weren't that difficult as I discovered afterwards, but as a person playing the wrong games for a long time (looking at you again CoD!) I really didn't know what to do at certain points. So valve assumes you have something resembling a brain when playing this game. Shooting and guns feel great. Animations are good too. Only thing that feels old are the textures and models but what do you expect from a game this old? Of course being on PC offers great options like texture mods or even complete overhauls/standalones with Black Mesa being the most popular. Only thing is, the last part of the game is not ready for Black Mesa yet so that's why I didn't play that instead.Only thing I didn't sometimes like was the jumping. After a jump you seem to 'slip away' but maybe that's just me. Not really worth mentioning but sometimes It was frustrating to jump from one platform to another. If you want to rush a quick singleplayer game DO NOT play this game, this game is not for you. It's not the quick-fix singleplayer game you want to blast through in a couple mere hours. You need to relax and take time to play this jewel. And when you do, you will be rewarded a great experience that will change your look on singleplayers.PS: Go buy Half-Life 2 if you don't have it already!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												The best thing happened to me back in 2004, it was the year that the PC game Half-Life entered my life. I remember playing the demo, Half-Life: Uplink and going crazy for it. So, what did I think of the full game?It blew my F**KING mind! Mere words are insufficient to describe how freaking AWESOME this game was (and still is). I shall however attempt to do just that.The story is excellent. You begin as Gordon Freeman, a scientist in a secret laboratory complex called Black Mesa. The suspense builds as you make your way to the test labs and then, once there, it all goes horribly wrong. Your world is thrown upside down. Black Mesa has suffered a catastrophic system failure. Your friends and colleagues are dead or dying. It seems you are trapped far underground. But worse is yet to come.Combat is good and fun seeing enemies gibbed by your explosives. There is a lot to explore. The facility is vast, although not every door can be opened. Music is good and fits into the location of Black Mesa and the level you are on. Enemies are varied and vary in ability. Each section/level has its own theme and look, along with its own challenges.Half-Life was helped back in the day by the hundreds of mods that gamers made, enhancing and extending the Black Mesa complex. With them, the game seemed to last forever, which is no bad thing.The game comes with multiplayer and I must say was an absolute delight to be involved in. I spent many hours with my friends competing and having much fun in the process. I actually became rather good at it, if I do say so myself.After over 15 years the graphics obviously shows its age but in all honesty, who cares? I don't. It's actually one of the reasons I love the game and have such fond memories of it. Most of the character models look and sound the same, so making out who is who is almost impossible, which shows in the sequel.There may be Half-Life II and Black Mesa, which are graphically superior but if not already done so, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND you play this game. You shall not be disappointed.10/10 (for its time)

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												When this game was release I was just turning 2, so I never got to play it.I've played for almost 10 hours so far and loved every second of it, you're always doing something; I haven't experienced any boring sections yet, every section has something to do, enemies to kill, somewhat puzzle-ish scenarios, or an objective you must figure out.The game gives you information from generic scientist surviors you meet, security personell (which you can also request that they help you fight, although the AI for them is terrible by today's standards, they can prove useful at times) and what seems to a army loudspeaker. Other times you figure it out on your own. Graphically it's nothing compared to today's standards but Valve has made HD textures, which are on by default. You can also get another out there on the internet although it may not be worth your time. There isn't anything that is going to improve the visuals drastically, but honestly the game is fine without, it's still very playable and it's in no way going to hinder your enjoyment.Gameplay is enjoyable and satisfying, the simple first person gunplay is great; pick up ammo, shoot, reload and stand behind cover, and reload whenever you can. Shooting alien crabs and those who they have taken over is relativley easy but a lot of fun. Shooting soldiers is a huge amount of fun, and it's where you have to think more about what you are doing and use the more varied weapons you have in your arsenal; they can be simple hand guns, revolvers, machine guns, shot guns, cross bows, grenades, etc.It's an enjoyable classic game, you shouldn't miss this out in your life. Come on, get it, and play it.

												It's a revolutionary game for gaming industry. Simply a classic. Half Life is a game every FPS fan should have in their libary. It's a game that set the standard for its genre.It's a game was far ahead of its time. Unlike other games of its time, it did not force gamers to read paragraphs or watch cutscenes that explain the game’s story. Instead, Half Life throws you right into the life of an average scientist, Gordon Freeman, who finds himself in the middle of an extraordinary adventure. Every moment in the game is experienced through the eyes of Gordon Freeman, and real-time scripted events allow the gamers to react to changes around. For its time, it was groundbreaking.It's a game you can still enjoy today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2013
												Am I really sitting here writing about why Half-Life is good? Yes, I am, but that's because it's so amazingly fantastic, so mind-blowingly good, so unquestionably a masterpiece, that it deserves to have what has already been said about it millions of times said again by me. If there was any doubt in my mind that video games are art, it has been eradicated by this game and it's sequel. This may seem like an odd choice for claiming games are art, but I believe it has the depth, complexity, and emotional attachment that a true work of art has. People latch on to games like Braid as examples of games as art because they outwardly appear to be "artsy" games, with vague plots and symbolism and plenty of emotional torment thrown at you, but once you look deeper a certain amount of pretentiousness is revealed, and you have to question how meaningful such works really are. Half-Life is not pretentious. It is not trying to appear "artsy," because it knows it has enough value to not have to hide behind such a facade to convince the public of it's worth. It may seem silly to reccomend such a famous game because "everyone's played it," but no matter how famous a game is there will always be someone who hasn't played it (I know I have a whole bucket list of essential titles that remain unplayed, such as Final Fantasy VI and Resident Evil 4), and if that person is you, rectify the situation as soon as possible. It remains a staple of any gamer's collection for a reason. Just be careful dismounting ladders. Fall damage is a ♥♥♥♥♥ in this game.Score: 10/10

												Half-Life is a game about an evil mastermind named G-Man who creates a clone army at the Black Mesa Research Facility. He is about to launch his invasion of the surface when his arch-rivals, the peaceful alien races of Xen, suddenly attack and begin to wipe out his hapless clone army while destroying the facility. Gordon Freeman, one of G-Man's henchmen, must stop the meddling aliens from ruining G-Man's plans forever! But just when you thought things were silly enough, the US government catches wind of G-Man's intention and sends in a scary (CALL OF DUTY) black ops (IS SICK) squad to kill everyone and seize the facility for their own means! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												One of the best games to have ever been created, Half-Life revolves around Gordon Freeman, a new scientist to the Black Mesa facility, trying to survive against zombies, aliens, military forces, and spec ops. With the aid of fellow scientist, Gordon Freeman goes around the facility seeking to stop the invading aliens who seem to be teleporting onto Earth. Simultaneously, the military has come to silence all Black Mesa workers in hopes of covering up the castastrophic incident. Traveling through the insides of the facility to the mountain sides to the strange alien world, there is always danger around the corner along with a few puzzles to get around. Even with a variety of weapons to get ahead of others, you may find yourself in a tough situation from time to time. The story behind all this is full of amazement as it goes on to the sequal.Multi-player is also an enjoyment with several maps to choose from, custom or otherwise. Players can always find an enjoyment when playing against each other whether it be underground with water traps to a bomb testing facility to Homer Simpson's house.One thing I would like to point out is the over-powered Tao Gun, a lazor weapon capable of killing people through walls with one charged shot and catapulting yourself across the map.
