number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												Few games have been as important to the video game industry as Half-Life. The first game to directly integrate storytelling into its gameplay, it revolutionized the FPS genre. The player never leaves the perspective of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who becomes an unlikely hero after finding himself in the middle of a disaster.This game is filled with non-stop action, and it presents no cutscenes, leaving the player in full control of Gordon's actions during the whole game. Its story is one of the best stories ever told in games, and this is where it all started.It also presents plenty of detailed environments, and you really get the feeling of exploring a top secret research facility; and all the different weapons provide a rewarding experience during fight scenes.This game is highly recommendable. Not just that, this game MUST be played by every gamer out there. You surely won't regret it.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Half-Life (stylized as HλLF-LIFE) is a science fiction first-person shooter video game developed by Valve, released in 1998 by Sierra Studios for Microsoft Windows. It was Valve's debut product and the first in the Half-Life series. Players assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, who must fight his way out of a secret research facility after a teleportation experiment goes disastrously wrong, fighting enemies and solving puzzles.Before this game I had only played Team Fortress 2, Half Life 2, Half Life 2 ; Episode One and Two, Portal and Counter strike.I hadent had much knowledge on this game but I loved Half Life 2 and was intrested on how this one would play out.This game is incredibly fun, it has great gameplay that has held expectations up high for FPS games. It has good graphics for a game from 1998 and has perfect weapons, character models and storytelling10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												     Just finished Half-Life and I must say it was quite an adventure. For being such an old game it is very good! It took a very long time to get through the whole game and the story was quite extensive and very interesting! I played this game simply because I  love the Portal series so very much! Since Portal and Half-Life are linked together I figured I would get more of an explanation as to how the two game link and while portal was never hinted to, for obvious reasons (it didn't come out for another 7 or so years, duh!), I could see how the stories linked on the simple basis of the apocolypse. I'm excited to find out the rest of the story in Half life 2!    The controls are useful and it is very nice that you can save at any point rather than just key points, this is an extremely helpful feature, especially for the ever frustrating jump climb! :P The gameplay is fun and flows pretty smoothly. I have no big problems with the run/jump style. The Story was phenomenol and I really enjoyed it! They put a lot of work and effort into building a great story line.     The Dialogue is pretty good. You never hear Gordon speak, only scientists, guards, etc. which at times is quite comical. The Level Design is also phenominal. They did a lot of work on putting out as many unique levels as possible and they did a great job. The AI is not too much of a problem and I think it was quite advanced for its time. The enemy wont shoot at you if they cant see you which is actually quite nice. They sometimes get into a more strategic formation to face me which is also good work.      The World Design, along with the level design, is phenomenol. The story is linear, but with good cause. It is a story, not an RPG choice adventure. VALVe tells the story via game and I really like it! The Graphics are absolutely lesser than now, but I love it! The nostalgia is great! I really appreciate the old game made available for current PCs because a lot of the modern games can only be supported by super computers and its really nice to be able to play a quality game on a netbook, crappy PC, etc. Finally, the sound goes along with the nostalgia and I love the 8-bit sound effects and voices and music. The music is few and far between, but that just makes it all the more appreciated.      This is definitely one of the video games you need to play. Please support this amazing company, they created Steam and many wonderful games, like Portal and Half Life. Buy this game!The Review outline style was taken from Game Developers Tycoon. Please also consider that game for it is great! :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												This game still holds as one of the best first person shooters, specially because of it's multiplayer. It hasn't aged that well, unlike it's successor. Glitches in the single player campaign can be very annoying, but if you like old games, you must play this. It's a very long game, has little focus on story, so the action is nonstop as you travel trough a lot of different environments, the gameplay never gets boring. And if you already played Black Mesa Source, I still recommend this just because of the multiplayer.The multiplayer is very unique and fun. The different kinds of alien weaponry and the possibility to use some of then to move and jump around makes it very hard to master. I always return to play it because the multiplayer on modern war games always bores me, trying to be realistic and balanced, while in Half-Life you just make a mess with ridiculously overpowered weapons and movement mechanics, it's fast, it's awesome. Half-Life 2 Deathmatch was just not the same in comparison. If Valve decides to make Half-Life 3's multiplayer just like the first game, with more maps, more overpowered alien weapons, faster movement, and a remake of the crossfire map, it will be the best multiplayer game ever, outselling all Call of Duty games combined.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												Few games have been as important to the video game industry as Half-Life. The first game to directly integrate storytelling into its gameplay, it revolutionized the FPS genre. The player never leaves the perspective of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who becomes an unlikely hero after finding himself in the middle of a disaster.This game is filled with non-stop action, and it presents no cutscenes, leaving the player in full control of Gordon's actions during the whole game. Its story is one of the best stories ever told in games, and this is where it all started.It also presents plenty of detailed environments, and you really get the feeling of exploring a top secret research facility; and all the different weapons provide a rewarding experience during fight scenes.This game is highly recommendable. Not just that, this game MUST be played by every gamer out there. You surely won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16
												Does graphics matter?-NoWell you're looking at the right game! This game blew up gaming industry. This game means alot to me. Back in the day when i had the worst internet. I used to go to my uncles house and set up a LAN party to play with neighbours. Everybody had fun, we all laughed. We didn't even get the game. We used to act annoying and lock ourselfes to the nuke room on Crossfire (what ever it's called) and get everybody mad. We thought the graphics were so damn great. We never got the chance to join servers because our internet wasn't enough to do so.  It was fun. Then we grew up. Everything is amazing now. High tech computers, amazingly fast internet etc... But nowdays i never get a chance to play with my old fellas. I think Valve remastered it. I don't really like the new skins for guns but nothing has changed. The community is same, there are still great servers with players. The storyline on the other hand. At one point this game starts to go point to point which plays a big role in speedrunning. It never gets boring how much you play it. Amazing bugs and tricks still work fine. The game scared me when i was a little kid. I didn't understand one thing because i had no idea how to speak english. Nowdays when i play it, i get excited almost everytime. Gr8 Game.

												Easily one of my favorite games of all time half life has a story that will keep you entralled all the way to the end and changed the way First Person Shooters could be developd as before there games like Doom and Wolfenstein 3d that focused on puzzle solving and mowing down enemys similarly to Half Life. Half Life was made by Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington  and was made using a heavily modified version of The Quake engine known as Gold Src.The reason I enjoy Half life so much is that it didnt need cutscenes because everything would unfold in front of you so you felt like you were experiencing it first hand. In the end if you can get this game i do reccomend it

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Honestly, this game is SO MUCH BETTER than Half Life 2.For the record, I have zero nostalgia for anything Valve; I hardly played any PC games until around 2014. As someone who had no experience with keyboard+mouse, first person shooters, or games made before 2000, Half Life 1 is possibly the best introduction to all three of those things. Controls are a little wonky (probably cause of its age), but is accessable enough for newbies like myself to master it by the end of the game. There are more than a few spots where you'll get lost, don't know what to do, be forced to do some stupid platforming/firefight, etc. but the parts that are well polished are what make it worthwhile.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. Almost everything about this game is ahead of it's time. Gameplay, Graphics, and the AI. The guards in the Science lab (Black Mesa) follow you well, and do whatever they can to help you, and their not Half-Bad at it. (Bad pun) The roaches flock to dead bodies, and run away from you, and your flashlight for example. And the military forces distract and then flank you too, which adds some difficulty. This game will occasionally laugh in your face while you try to do something to progress, but it's okay because even though you usually end up dying in the end of the trick, there is usually an autosave just before the trick to give you the chance to correct your mistake. You can also save whenever you want to, and load back to any of the saves you have made.And believe me, you might just need to do that a few times. Sometimes you got a part, and then you can't get past it because you have almost no health by the time you get there. But it's okay, this game is fun and satisfying. You can also make corpses explode with only a crowbar, and that alone is enough to make me get this game. 420/10Also, for some reason, I think I was the only person in the world who actually dug around in the video settings a bit, and you can actually play through the whole game with better looking weapons with clear textures, and they look entirely different. And you can actually read the words BLACK MESA on the guards' badges. I played through the entirety of the game with the HD models, so when I saw playthroughs and screenshots of the game with people using the low quality models I was kind of confused.

												Half-Life is not only the most influential and important FPS ever made, it's also the best. The game excels at both combat and ambiance. Where other games rely on jump-scares or pitch black environments all of the time, Half-Life gives those elements to you in doses small enough that they don’t become stale or overdone. The combat is also excellent, though the controls are a little loose by today’s standards. The game even does platforming and puzzling well. Overall, the game is a must-own for any FPS fan, and even one for those not as FPS-inclined.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												HALF-LIFE. WRITTEN REVIEW NOT COMPLETEquote. Scientist: [playing with tie] Why do we all have to wear these ridiculous ties?. Developed by Valve and released in 1998Pros and Conspros. Everythingcons. Nothing 10/10 MasterpiceceSTORYLINEA mysterious Alien Artifact has been recovered and brought to a top-secret research facility in the Black Mesa. When newcomer Dr. Gordon Freeman is assigned to physically test the artifact, things go very wrong when the artifact opens a destructive and unstable portal to Xen, a planet in a different dimension. Gordon blacks out, and awakes in a now crippled and ruined research facility. When Freeman and the survivors of this ordeal discover the portal has allowed its inhabitants-deadly alien creatures-to enter the facility, they realise that they must call the government for help. The government, however, already has plans to contain this incident by silencing the witnesses. Half life's story is a very diverse and confusing one, but is still executed brilliantly. since Half Life does not rely on cut scenes, there are moments when subtle important plot references are hinted towards key features of the story, but these references can be left unnoticed especially on a first play-through. This really depends on the player and their play style if you are to notice these references. Therefore this game mechanic should not be seen as a flaw rather as an attempt to try something new that valve knew very well wouldn’t mix with everyone.GAMEPLAYHalf life is the most influential First Person Game Ever Made. This is best exemplified through its game play mechanics. Let me explain. Growing up as a young grommet the only fps game I was familiar with was DOOM. At the time DOOM was piratically seen as the best pc game of all time. All fps games two follow copied the DOOM formula, all except half life. You see Doom had .NO Apparent storyline.NO Interesting characters .NO Absorbing atmosphere [It felt very arcade like].And no real apparent goalThe game was really a stress reviler where you just shoot s.hit and blow c.unts up. Not saying DOOM is a bad game. DOOM is one of my favourite games its just that Half life beat DOOM at the fps formula in all ways by Half Life having .A fantastic and engaging story..A scary immersive atmosphere..A roster of witty and interesting characters..A simplified moving mechanic.A mechanic where you could look up and down.{ thank F.UCK for that }.A Mixture of action and Puzzles.And a game with an apparent goal from the very start.You see Half Life wasn’t one of those games where you would just shoot s.hit and blows c.unts up. Half Life was the first real fps game to feel like a immersive gaming experience. Therefore we have half life to thank for saving and changing what was commonly thought of as the First Person Shooter Genre.PACINGHalf Life Pacing is Executed very well. The game has the whole survival horror game feel to it and the game really exemplifies this through a sense of dread. At the start of the game it is apparent that you need to escape the black mesa facility but only an hour down the track you start to lose recognition of that thought and just have the mindset of surviving, and that is why this games pacing is so good. You never quite feel like you have an objective to do rather you just feel you have to survive. and coupling this with the fine selection of jump-scares and mind blowing scripted events it truly holds up. LEVEL DESIGN Valve has a name for level design in their games. Its hard to describe on paper but no gaming developer team does it like valve, you just have to see it for yourself, I mean talk about attention to detail. Before Half Life level design in fps video games were very simplistic and felt like an arcade experience. Half Life's level design was truly ahead of its time. Structures would collapse, you could interact with all most everything from the environment, and the game used a clever use of scripted events through the level design. It is very hard to explain on paper but you can tell a lot of work was put into this category of game design for half life.IMMERSIONImmersion, Probably The Fundamental Aspect Of Game Design That Every Game Director Should Take Seriously, Gabe Newell Certainty Did With Half-Life. You See Half-Life Never Breaks The Immersion Because The Game Never Allows The Player To Stop Playing. This Is Because The Game Doesn't Consist Of Cut-Scenes Or Any Other Immersion Breakers. The Game Never Says, ''Hey Maybe You Should Take A Break''. The Only Thing Controlling Your Will To Stop Or Keep Playing Is The Player's Own Demanding Ambition.SOUNDTRACKHalf-Life soundtrack consists of a techno and ambience like tracks. One of Half Life's key elements two its atmosphere is said soundtrack. Half Life's soundtrack always seems to change conveniently creating a completely different mood and atmosphere to the last segment of the game. The use of ambience like tracks for the more creepy, mysterious moments through out the game coupled with the techno prodigy like tracks for the scripted action moments through out the game really create an experience like no other. Not two mention the end credits theme witch really feels rewarding and catchy... here is a link to the end credits theme soundtrack 


YouTube™ Video: Half Life OST - Closing Theme 

			Views: 252,348		

			Half Life credits' music

content:
Posted: November 1, 2013
												Am I really sitting here writing about why Half-Life is good? Yes, I am, but that's because it's so amazingly fantastic, so mind-blowingly good, so unquestionably a masterpiece, that it deserves to have what has already been said about it millions of times said again by me. If there was any doubt in my mind that video games are art, it has been eradicated by this game and it's sequel. This may seem like an odd choice for claiming games are art, but I believe it has the depth, complexity, and emotional attachment that a true work of art has. People latch on to games like Braid as examples of games as art because they outwardly appear to be "artsy" games, with vague plots and symbolism and plenty of emotional torment thrown at you, but once you look deeper a certain amount of pretentiousness is revealed, and you have to question how meaningful such works really are. Half-Life is not pretentious. It is not trying to appear "artsy," because it knows it has enough value to not have to hide behind such a facade to convince the public of it's worth. It may seem silly to reccomend such a famous game because "everyone's played it," but no matter how famous a game is there will always be someone who hasn't played it (I know I have a whole bucket list of essential titles that remain unplayed, such as Final Fantasy VI and Resident Evil 4), and if that person is you, rectify the situation as soon as possible. It remains a staple of any gamer's collection for a reason. Just be careful dismounting ladders. Fall damage is a ♥♥♥♥♥ in this game.Score: 10/10

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Even though it's nearing 20 years old, Half-Life is still a very immersive and cinematic shooter, and years ahead of its time. The level design is great, and it feels spacious without being too open (I never got lost, which is pretty amazing given my track record). There are some great scripted events which lend to the cinematic feel, and while the game doesn't usually have music, when it does kick in it's always super hype. There are also some neat and well-designed bosses which require more that brute force to take down. One of the best single-player FPS experiences.

Other games tried to copy the DOOM formula which had a muscular guy who finds joy in shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥and saves th day with a kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtrack in the backround. But HL made something original. You now have a scientist who is not used to being a "hero" who saves has to get out of Black Mesa or else he'll die. 												This game made me rethink first-person shooters. It's extremely well done in just about every regard. At this point, the graphics are outdated. But I never minded. My only gripe with Half-Life is that it's too long for what it is. A lot of the situations it puts you through are repeated with only subtle tweeks along the way. This 18 chapter story could've been done in 12-14, and the whole game would've felt more concise as a result. That being said, it's still an amazing classic and a  must-play for gamers. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												It's refreshing to still be able to play and enjoy an old jewel like this game, and for those of you young enough not to know the importance of this game, back in its day this classic shooter revolutionized the industry. And now we can enjoy it once again understanding the game's age and that we can't possibly expect it to be on par with modern titles in terms of looks. I played the game through several playthroughs, and at the difficulty I played it, it was quite challenging with quite a few reloads to get it done. This quick save/reload cycle is pretty much an inherent part of how the game plays and it got VERY annoying with several instances me getting close to rage quit it. However the game always won me back no matter what! I encountered little bugs in my experience with it, and I didn't play it in my normal gaming rig but instead in a very crappy laptop. This was due to an idea I have that games from the pre-1080p era should be played in laptops so that they don't look too pixelated and the game played very smoothly with very little bugs.Conclusion: This game is a very nice retro experience, challenging to the point of making you rage quit, but with the power of winning you back after every cry of anger!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The game that started it all; Half-Life. You play as Gordon Freeman, a scientist with a PhD in Theoretical Physics, who works in Black Mesa. You're running late for your experiment. Although, after this, you'll wish you were on a sick day.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This game is a masterpiece. It has an immersive, original plotline, excellently executed enemies (with their own weaknesses and strengths, mind you), epic weapons, and great graphics that even still hold up today. The game builds an ominous atmosphere right away in the intro. You're on the tram, and you pass by a radioactive "leak". That wasn't an accident, Mr. Freeman, but a hint at the Black Mesa servers' condition. When you're off the tram, you head to the locker room (right after blowing up Magnusson's casserole, of course) and get your HEV (Hazardous Environment suit) suit and head over to the experimentation lab, where the entire chaotic mess begins.If you want to know more, play it for yourself.Graphics: 9/10Story: 10/10Soundtrack: 9.5/10Gameplay: 10/10Replayability: 9/10Overall Average: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
 Review of Half Life 1 So I always try to continue the meme of "Where is Half life 3?", but the it struck me... I haven't even played the original game and I should be ashamed of that!I picked up the game for 3$, fired it up and instantly fell in love with it. When starting I kinda wanted to freerun the game as the mechanics felt so good. Of course they weren't realistic as the new games, but sometimes I just wish more games would be done this way( without the wobbly left right movement). AS I tried to rush the game I soon realized this game requiered some skill. So I had to be a little more strategic. I loved the storyand the monsters in the game. Sometimes I found it too easy to advance into the next chapter as some enemies were stupid like hell, most of the time I strugeled to advance(Ok, I admit. I looked up a yt tutorial).The thing that bothered me the most was the audio quality. Now I'm no programmer, but I think they could have done better even in 1999.Weapon handling was also a blast and found some wepons to be quite unique. To recap all of this in a sentence I would have to say: If you enjoy a game with a fine story, good weapons, bad AI and good graphics (for it's time), this is the game for you.I somewhat enjoyed the game in the same way I enjoyed the oringinal doom. This is the game that set a new industry standard and would be a shame if you didn't have it in your library. Overall this game is a 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Half-Life 1 was probably the first game I ever played and strongly got me into PC gaming. Alongside Team Fortress Classic and Counter-Strike, I was so eager to swap from using a family PC to having my own PC just to simply play this game - that's how amazing it was, and still is! For its age, it has a really fantastic feel to it and an engine that has adapted for uses even today (such as Sven Co-op and other MODs).The best thing about Half-Life of course is, as mentioned just now, the MODs that people create for this game. The GoldSrc engine is the only engine I see still being used very frequently nowadays and has such a great potential for newbie developers or even professional developers. Personally I have probably done everything possible with the engine, including map making, media (video/audio creation), modelling and more - it's a really great way to learn how to make your own MOD or possibly even your own game.The actual game itself (Half-Life, its story and the multiplayer) is also incredible. The story is unique (and with the newer Half-Life games in the series, it's still unique!) and the multiplayer is addicting - especially on the MODs (TFC, CS, etc)!I simply can't recommened this game enough - it's genuinely one of the best games out there!

												The game is visually decent, especially when you consider its age.I find the physics engine a little bit annoying at times, but otherwise it is well designed. Unfortunately, there are a few bugs that are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ I even managed to find one that affects the gameplay drastically, preventing the player from progressing. Hopefully, latter games in the series are free from this kind of issues.Despite that and a few other minor nuisances, I consider the technical aspect of the game to be generally good.The plot of Half-Life is the game's strong point. As you play, it gets more tense.I don't particularly like the multiplayer mode, but that's not really a disadvantage, since the game seems to be more focused on the single-player campaign, which is awesome.In short, Half-Life is old, but it's worth playing. I think I'll save up some money for HL2.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												HALF-LIFE. WRITTEN REVIEW NOT COMPLETEquote. Scientist: [playing with tie] Why do we all have to wear these ridiculous ties?. Developed by Valve and released in 1998Pros and Conspros. Everythingcons. Nothing 10/10 MasterpiceceSTORYLINEA mysterious Alien Artifact has been recovered and brought to a top-secret research facility in the Black Mesa. When newcomer Dr. Gordon Freeman is assigned to physically test the artifact, things go very wrong when the artifact opens a destructive and unstable portal to Xen, a planet in a different dimension. Gordon blacks out, and awakes in a now crippled and ruined research facility. When Freeman and the survivors of this ordeal discover the portal has allowed its inhabitants-deadly alien creatures-to enter the facility, they realise that they must call the government for help. The government, however, already has plans to contain this incident by silencing the witnesses. Half life's story is a very diverse and confusing one, but is still executed brilliantly. since Half Life does not rely on cut scenes, there are moments when subtle important plot references are hinted towards key features of the story, but these references can be left unnoticed especially on a first play-through. This really depends on the player and their play style if you are to notice these references. Therefore this game mechanic should not be seen as a flaw rather as an attempt to try something new that valve knew very well wouldn’t mix with everyone.GAMEPLAYHalf life is the most influential First Person Game Ever Made. This is best exemplified through its game play mechanics. Let me explain. Growing up as a young grommet the only fps game I was familiar with was DOOM. At the time DOOM was piratically seen as the best pc game of all time. All fps games two follow copied the DOOM formula, all except half life. You see Doom had .NO Apparent storyline.NO Interesting characters .NO Absorbing atmosphere [It felt very arcade like].And no real apparent goalThe game was really a stress reviler where you just shoot s.hit and blow c.unts up. Not saying DOOM is a bad game. DOOM is one of my favourite games its just that Half life beat DOOM at the fps formula in all ways by Half Life having .A fantastic and engaging story..A scary immersive atmosphere..A roster of witty and interesting characters..A simplified moving mechanic.A mechanic where you could look up and down.{ thank F.UCK for that }.A Mixture of action and Puzzles.And a game with an apparent goal from the very start.You see Half Life wasn’t one of those games where you would just shoot s.hit and blows c.unts up. Half Life was the first real fps game to feel like a immersive gaming experience. Therefore we have half life to thank for saving and changing what was commonly thought of as the First Person Shooter Genre.PACINGHalf Life Pacing is Executed very well. The game has the whole survival horror game feel to it and the game really exemplifies this through a sense of dread. At the start of the game it is apparent that you need to escape the black mesa facility but only an hour down the track you start to lose recognition of that thought and just have the mindset of surviving, and that is why this games pacing is so good. You never quite feel like you have an objective to do rather you just feel you have to survive. and coupling this with the fine selection of jump-scares and mind blowing scripted events it truly holds up. LEVEL DESIGN Valve has a name for level design in their games. Its hard to describe on paper but no gaming developer team does it like valve, you just have to see it for yourself, I mean talk about attention to detail. Before Half Life level design in fps video games were very simplistic and felt like an arcade experience. Half Life's level design was truly ahead of its time. Structures would collapse, you could interact with all most everything from the environment, and the game used a clever use of scripted events through the level design. It is very hard to explain on paper but you can tell a lot of work was put into this category of game design for half life.IMMERSIONImmersion, Probably The Fundamental Aspect Of Game Design That Every Game Director Should Take Seriously, Gabe Newell Certainty Did With Half-Life. You See Half-Life Never Breaks The Immersion Because The Game Never Allows The Player To Stop Playing. This Is Because The Game Doesn't Consist Of Cut-Scenes Or Any Other Immersion Breakers. The Game Never Says, ''Hey Maybe You Should Take A Break''. The Only Thing Controlling Your Will To Stop Or Keep Playing Is The Player's Own Demanding Ambition.SOUNDTRACKHalf-Life soundtrack consists of a techno and ambience like tracks. One of Half Life's key elements two its atmosphere is said soundtrack. Half Life's soundtrack always seems to change conveniently creating a completely different mood and atmosphere to the last segment of the game. The use of ambience like tracks for the more creepy, mysterious moments through out the game coupled with the techno prodigy like tracks for the scripted action moments through out the game really create an experience like no other. Not two mention the end credits theme witch really feels rewarding and catchy... here is a link to the end credits theme soundtrack 


YouTube™ Video: Half Life OST - Closing Theme 

			Views: 252,348		

			Half Life credits' music

content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												1998 Is called the best year in gaming by many. Half-Life is part of the reason why. For it's time, not many games, especially shooters, could boast about bringing about a realistic and highly immersive environment like Half-Life did. It may of aged visually and the sound effects are all but weak by 2011's standards but I wouldn't bet on anything nearing the quality of Half-Life's presentation and broad level architecture. Valve certainly has come along way since then but the basis of Half-Life has played triumphantly to the success of all their subsequent IPs and is all the proof you need that powerful original and inspired design can go a long way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Half-Life is an all time classic masterpiece. It's a story rich game, full of revolutionizing gameplay material for its time. Its interactive atmosphere, creates a sense of realism to the player. While the graphics were amazing for its time, they are clearly outdated, but either way this game does deserve a play as it is truly amazing (Gameplay wise, and story wise). Gameplay wise, Half-Life's shooting and combat is smooth, and the interactive environment can cause pretty cool easter eggs, as well as intriguing story pieces to uncover throughout the Black Mesa Facility. Story wise, Half-Life focuses on a silent protagonist, which may seem strange for a story rich game. However, Half-Life's character's silence causes the player to react rather than the character, letting the player feel as if they were in the game, and make choices that reflect on themselves not on the character, which really causes the player to feel as if they form a part of the story. I won't spoil the story but I have to say it is unique for its time, and not everyone will be attracted to it, but it's worth a play from my side. :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It is unfortunate to say this, but as great a game as Half-Life is, time has not been good to it. When I played the game, it was sad to see how old the game has become. Nonetheless, this is the game to shatter all games for almost a decade.Video games have so much to owe to Half-Life, every single FPS that has come out since then, owes something to Half-life.If you played Half-Life rather thoughtlessly, you may think that the game is seriously overrated, but the story, the dialouge, and the characters in Half-Life are very subtle. Don't expect this game to parade itself as the best PC game of all time. It's modest that way.We can't really say much about the graphics or sound or the character models of Half-Life, as this game IS from 1998, but this game is big where is counts. The gameplay is solid, the story is quiet, - yet brilliant - and the level design is incredible. If you want to know how to make the best game the world has ever seen, go to Half-Life. I wish game designers of today would use this as a model, because you just don't get better.I may be raving about how great the game is, and in that case I have something BAD to say about it...I hate the bloody ladders in this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												After finally finishing this game I can say it was one of the best experiences I had with any game on steam. This game (for it's time) has great graphics, amazing gameplay, cool weapons (even cooler than Half Life 2's), hilarious moments with friendly NPCs, great AI that inspired many other games, a variety of  enemies, and a decent story to tie it up together with a few pretty cool "boss fights" where in most of them you can't shoot your way out and you need to figure out how to defeat them (although the game gives you pretty easy hints to figure out)  + Great Combat + Great Pacing + Great AI + Variety in enemies, weapons, and environments + Decent Story Notes: * Climbing ladders may be a problem for some (personally I had no problem with it but I can see why people complain). * Aside from an optional tutorial mission, this game doesn't hold your hand at all, and while it may be fun for me and others to explore by ourselves, some people may like an objective, a map, etc. * After finishing the game there are a ton of mods you can try. Final Score: 10/10

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												This game was a graphically impressive game back then, and to be honest it's gameplay lives up even now. It's fast paced action which will completely destroy you later on in single player if you jump into everything blindly, and that fast pace makes the multiplayer incredibly fun. It gets pretty chaotic with a lot of players. I suppose my only complaint about the multiplayer is how easy it is to get spawnkilled. Other than that, I can't think of too much wrong with the game for it's time, and I'd recommend buying it if you don't have it yet.EDIT:A small problem I have is when it autosaves. It sometimes does so at the worst imaginable times, like rounding a corner with a bunch of enemies while you have 1 health left. Of course one could always load the previous autosave, but it's still fairly annoying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												PROS: - Straight-foward story - Enjoyable gameplay - Perfect balance between ammo conservation and limitations - Player-friendly interactionsCONS: - Gordon feels too high over other characters - Story path is never explained to youOVERVIEW:     This game is really ♥♥♥♥ing good. It's pretty high up there, but NOT at the top. (Grab your pitchforks!) Half-Life is the first installment into the series and does not fail to impress. With easy to look at and understand graphics and hands-down some of the finest crafted gameplay in any game i've ever played, this game is something I could replay anytime. Most of you should already know the story and its characters, only because its a Valve game, so i'll spare the story details. While playing through Half-Life, you may notice the crazy balance between ammo and limits. There are a lot of risk-taking moments and sometimes even have you leaving to backtrack for more ammo, which does not feel tedious at all. All interactions in this game are centered around YOU. It feels like you are important to this world, like you really are trying to save it. Overall it just makes for fine story-telling. As for Gordon himself and the way other characters perceive him, it just feels dumb. EVERY other character just feels like they are lower than you, which doesn't show a challenge in the story. I don't know if Valve tried to play a safe-route when it came to the story, but it disapointed me when you felt higher than everyone. It's like having a route, A to B. At B there is a super weapon that you need but instead of walking that route, the game just brings it to you and it does not feel so rewarding.This game is great and highly enjoyable. I'd state my cons at more of a personal pinpoint, but it's really up to you on how you feel about it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Half Life is a zombie game in the perspective of one of those responsible for it's origins. In the Black Mesa scientific research and developemt facility (Interesting Banter: Black Mesa roughly translates to Black Table, with Mesa meaning Table in spanish. #TheMoreYouKnow) Gordon Freeman, age 27, inadvertently causes the apocalypse, when a rare crystal found from the facility's experiments with teleportation is places under a super-powered analyzer, which then overloads and opens a wormhole to an alien dimension full of creatures that leech onto your head and gain control over your body, creating zombies.Lost intrest yet? No? Good.Armed with a crowbar, a mech suit, and a series of shooty-shooty bang bang tubes, you face the onslaught, prepared to get to the surface and call for help. Does this go well? Buy the game and see.*This game is old. Like, 1998 old. But when it came out, it revolutionalised the gaming industry with it's unique storytelling and gameplay style. It is a first person shooter that will be remembered for years to come, despite it being 16 next month.However, this game can be PUNISHINGLY dificult, especiallly in later levels. No doubt will you find yourself wishing you'd picked an easier difficulty at some point in the game.Having said this, though, Half Life is still damn enjoyable, even to this day.Verdict: This is a damn fine shooter.8/10. Would happily play again and again a few times.*SPOILERS  The US Army intend to neutralize the threat by killing every living, undead, and alien thing in the facility, It's fun. You get to shoot the same 3 soldier models over and over. :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												This is going to be a long review so in short: Half-Life is a classic game, that everyone who likes the FPS genre should play. The price is right, the game is entertaining, and the series of more recent games (Half-Life 2) it leads into are incredible, historicaly, gameplay-wise, and story-wise. Worth your money; you'll enjoy it. In a little more detail: I played Half-Life first, around 2 years ago and I've since logged about a hundred hours in the game. I've played through it 9 or 10 times. I had been needing something new to play after finishing Portal 2 and Half-Life was on sale. I asked a friend if I should play it and he said no - that it was boring, but the price was so good I bought it and tried it anyways, and I was immediately hooked. I've since bought the game for several friends, and it's the first title I bring up to anyone asking for a game reccomendation. Half-Life is an old game. I'm not going to pretend that I would be thrilled with this game if it had come out yesterday. If I bought this game in 2016, let's face it, I'd want a refund. The graphics are extremely dated, the movement is a little tough to get used to, and the AI is seriously lacking. Gabe Newell would be getting an angry email. In 1998, when it was released however, Half-Life was a revolutionary game, with unique and new methods of story telling, exciting new mechanics, and realistic AI. The ability to jump was still a relatively cool new development in the gaming world, and the ability to crouch-jump was very new. Half-Life has a large variety of interesting weapons, and the enemies move and interact with the player in advanced ways for a 90's game. Enemies will follow you, take cover, switch between different types of attacks, call in other enemies, and more. The puzzles in Half-Life are what 90's gamers would have wanted. While jumping puzzles nowadays are lazy and annoying, they were popular in the 90's in the FPS genre, because being able to jump at all was still somwehat of a novelty. The chapter "On A Rail" is my LEAST favourite chapter, and annoys the hell out of me, but like the Ravenholm chapter in Half-Life 2, it would have been an exciting way for gamers to test out a fun new game mechanic. The story is told entirely through Gordon's eyes, which creates a level of immersion that had never been seen before in the FPS genre, and that still holds up today. Even despite dated graphics, I still found myself deeply engrossed in the game's world. Half-Life was one of the (if not the) first FPS game to be highly story-oriented. Prior to Half-Life, the FPS genre was not usually chosen for story telling. Valve took the FPS genre to the next level by creating a game that is dynamic in BOTH gameplay, and story. My apologies if that paragraph was a little messy; I have a lot of thoughts. Now I hear you, it's not 1998 anymore, so whether or not Half-Life was a good game THEN is only part of the story. Half-Life can be a revolutionary game-changing (no pun intended) game and still suck to play today, and the reviews section is supposed to give you some idea of whether or not you actually want to spend money on this game and play it. Half-Life is worth a play, 18 years after it's release, in 2016, and it's worth paying your ten dollars to get to do that, in my humble opinion. People dont play games out of context. When I bought and played Half-Life the first time, I bought it to enjoy a classic game. If you expect to play a game with the same graphics quality as Portal 2 then you'll be dissapointed. If you expect to play Half-Life as it is (an 18 year old story-rich FPS) you will be blown away. Half-Life shattered my expectations for what an 18 year old game could be. Don't pretend the game is something it's not. If you're alright with playing an old game, Half-Life will not dissapoint. While some aspects of the game are dated, the core principles (weaponry, characters, story, and gameplay) stand up to time beautifully and the parts that do not (some puzzles, designs of some rooms and levels) do not take away from the over-all experience, and are still fun. Half-Life is fun, stands the test of time where it needs to, bears a great deal of gaming-history, and is the opening installment of one of the most (in my opinion) great game series of all time. For anyone who actually read this far: remember when there were rumours that Half-Life 3 would be released in February 2015? That was funny.

Posted: March 3, 2016
												Half life is Pure art inspired by the great GabeN in the sky. He sent us many steam sales which killed our wallets instantly, and i will be awaiting HL3 so he can decimate our wallets completely with no hopes of recovering. Half life has brilliant level design and simplistic graphics. This is why it is true art. It doesn't require fancy story line or graphics to be fun, It's just fun. similar to megaman and castlevania story isnt important, nor graphics, but the gameplay. Many people today dismiss 8-bit games like them as bad BECAUSE of their graphics, which overall is stupid, obviously. I really wish people played more games like this to show how good games can be without the graphics. (as long as they are pleasing to look at not barphic textures plasted everywhere) Backtracking in this game isnt needed until one part and its actually guided unlike most backtracking, which is excellent level design. Overall Design of the game and levels, fun factory and graphics are great and I look forward to playing more of the Half life series.

content:
Posted: February 22
												After finally finishing this game I can say it was one of the best experiences I had with any game on steam. This game (for it's time) has great graphics, amazing gameplay, cool weapons (even cooler than Half Life 2's), hilarious moments with friendly NPCs, great AI that inspired many other games, a variety of  enemies, and a decent story to tie it up together with a few pretty cool "boss fights" where in most of them you can't shoot your way out and you need to figure out how to defeat them (although the game gives you pretty easy hints to figure out)  + Great Combat + Great Pacing + Great AI + Variety in enemies, weapons, and environments + Decent Story Notes: * Climbing ladders may be a problem for some (personally I had no problem with it but I can see why people complain). * Aside from an optional tutorial mission, this game doesn't hold your hand at all, and while it may be fun for me and others to explore by ourselves, some people may like an objective, a map, etc. * After finishing the game there are a ton of mods you can try. Final Score: 10/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												What's the first thing that comes to mind, when reviewing a video game? Well, for me, it has to be the visual world that captures the core of our imaginations. And with this little gem called Half-Life, it's no exception that this game continues to boggle the mind and leave people wondering. There is more heart, creativity and scientific ingenuity there is in this one title than there is in most series and is arguably Valve's greatest achievement. (With over 50 game awards, it's a strong justification). Half-Life isn't just one of the greatest FPS games of all time. It's not because Half-Life is one of the best purchases you can ever get on Steam. Half-Life is quite simply, one of the greatest games ever made.When compared to certain FPS games in the past and modern times, which both heavily rely on long-winded cutscenes to glorify the main plotline, Half-Life annihilates this compulsed aspect, by detailing the plotlines that keeps the player still in control of the first-person viewpoint, leaving the cutscenes rolling while you still have full access to the gameplay and character controllability. For clarification, You will see through the eyes of Gordon Freeman at all times.The game is a constant puzzle; leaving the player to work at tasks that involve being locked into battle and overall puzzle solving to advance through the many challenges that wait up ahead. Most of the time, the story illuminates the puzzles by the actions to proceed, such as maze scenarios and building boxes to use as staircases. Though Half-Life has short-lived loading screens from time to time after leaving a certain area for a new one, the game has no levels. But, to make up for this traditional concept, the game is split into a number of mind-boggling chapters filled with rich story glory.To start off with this game's story, you're none other than Gordon Freeman. A young man who holds a Ph.D in theoretical physics who starts his daily grind back at the Black Mesa Research Facility; a fictional complex that is stranded in a remote desert located in the suburbs of New Mexico. Arriving late for work yet again, you take the tram system around the Black Mesa Research Facility and at this point, objectives that his game has fulfilled such as breath-taking visuals and movie quality animation begins to blossom. The tram sequence at the beginning of the game can only be summed up in one word; Incredible. It's as if the things that come flying at you from every angle and position, almost reminiscent of watching an action-packed movie, along with the credits of the producer's names proudly fading in and out on the corner of the screen.As you make your first step in the heavily secured facility, you're constantly reminded that you put on your Hazardous Enviromental suit, or the H.E.V suit for short. While all things are hunky-dory, those things soon turn to the worst very soon. After a failed experiment, involving a collision between a rare intergalactic specimen from another dimension with an Anti-Mass Spectrometer, the Black Mesa facility falls in ruins, meaning you are one of the only key survivors of the infamous ''Black Mesa Incident''. And with this, alien life-forms from the dimension of ''Xen'' are pulled from their dimension into ours and are running amok the ruined facility, along with the Army that storm the place after the gone, haywired facility's emergency call has been echoed. This of course doesn't make things any easier and you soon find yourself battling both the aliens and army.While there isn't exactly much to complain about, I would admit that guiding the chickened-out scientists and professors around the facility can be quite a pain now and again, as well as the alien life-form, Vortigaunt, from which you would have to wait and be patient for them to wreck down wooden doors in front of you, as you are not capable of doing that yourself. (You do start off with a crowbar, right?) As well as I'm probably not the only one who made the same mistake by killing them through a small opening, before they did in fact begin to tear down the doors. But then again, this is where the used scripted intermissions started to show, so that's an added bonus.For the long run, I've had fun and joy both reviewing this amazing game and playing this amazing game. If you haven't play Half-Life and you're not familiar with Half-Life, it's still a massive recommendation from me.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I've been conned by Valve, you lying hacks. I played the board game "Life" a lot as a child, so I bought this game thinking it going to be a digitized, virtual "prequel" to my favorite board game, which is why it was called "Half-Life" rather than just "Life." Boy was I mistaken. In this game, you play as Morgan Freeman, a mentally challenged, mute, scientist with heavy military experience working at Black Mamba research labs, when the mysterious character "Walter White" or "W-Man" gives the lab a Blue Crystal to "experiment" with, you open up an interdimensional portal to try and kill all your coworkers for being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to simply for showing up 30 minutes late. You succeed, and all hell breaks loose. The military also shows up to try and kill me for saying "Bush did 9/11" on the internet that one time, and you have to violently massacre them all just for doing their job. Although I did like Morgan Freeman's catchphrases, such as "Science rules!" or "It's cloberin' time!" Although that was it's only saving grace. All in all, this was terrible, and violent adaptation of a family board game. I never even got to the section where I choose if I want to go to college or not. Don't waste your hard-earned allowence money like I did, go to wal-mart, and purchase the full board game version, "Life." Take my word for it, video games and violence do not mix well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												The graphics are outdated, but the gameplay still holds. The gameplay is absolutely incredible, the story is interesting, and the controls are tighter then the skinny jeans I tried to wear in 7th grade. Exciting and thrilling despite the graphical limitations. It's almost difficult to believe this was made in 1998, well if the character models didn't look like they had been modeled out of clay and then dropped multiple times. I especially love the health and suit mechanics. It may be old, but it gives you a truly epic feel. Boss fights though scarce are some of my favorites. Thrilling, epic, awesome are all words that could be used to describe this game. I thought I had seen the real experience with the Black Mesa Half-Life 2 Mod, but I was mistaken. There are some differences, and the mod doesn't have the same atmosphere as the original. The original game is easier anyway and I respect that this game is one of the best out there and highly recommend that you play it if you get a chance. It works on even low-rate computers like mine and is way underpriced if you ask me. The music is great, and the level design is some of the best that I have ever seen. Among my few minor complaints are that the friendly NPCs are terrible at following, limited voice actor variety, crouch jumping is annoying, and what you need to do is sometimes nearly impossible to figure out without lots of trial and error. All in all one of my personal favorite games. 11 snarks out of 10.
